bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Angel Suarez-Solis, August 14, 1940

div1.p: Hench inquires whether Suarez-Solis would make an official statement that the address of number 102 Real Street is the same as in 1900.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Angel Suarez-Solis, August 14, 1940
div1.opener:
Copy to Moran
August 14, 1940
Senor Angel Suarez-Solis
#102 Real Street
Marianao, Havana
Cuba
My dear Senor Suarez-Solis:
div1.p:
You may remember that in April, Mr. Luis Pogolotti stopped
at your house with an American stranger and made some inquiries as to whether
the number of your house might have been changed since 1900. I was that
American.

I have been doing some medical historical researches on yellow
fever. Dr. Walter Reed, the American medical officer of the army, who, with
his colleagues confirmed the theory of Dr. Finlay of Havana, wrote in one of
his papers that yellow fever had been observed by him in the house #102
Real Street. It is my understanding that you told us that your house now
#102 Real Street must have been the same as that mentioned by Reed in 1900.
I understand that your father built this house in 1898, and I believe you
told me that some men on the staff of Dr. Fitzhugh Lee had lived in your
house at the time. I have been asked by the Cuban government to make a
report concerning many details of the yellow fever experiments, and I am
most anxious to have a statement from you telling me whether the number of
your house has been changed in all these years, so far as you know, and
whether any one in your family remembers anything about yellow fever victims
in your house at that time. I appreciate this help very greatly indeed.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
